alert.note: Alert for Barnes; Benson; Cass; Cavalier; Eddy; Grand Forks; Griggs; Nelson; Pembina; Ramsey; Ransom; Richland; Sargent; Steele; Towner; Traill; Walsh (North Dakota) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Eastern ND and Grand Forks (Northeastern North Dakota and Northwestern Minnesota)
info.headline: Hydrologic Outlook issued March 17 at 12:37PM CDT by NWS Eastern ND and Grand Forks
info.description: ...FAVORABLE MELT CONDITIONS TO CONTINUE THROUGH THE END OF THIS WEEK...SOMEWHAT ACCELERATED MELT AND RUNOFF EARLY NEXT WEEK... Yesterdays /Wednesdays/ unseasonably warm temperatures, with highs ranging from the 40s to low 50s, and overnight lows holding near the thaw point have given a kick start to the spring thaw process. Conditions over the next few days should help to stabilize that process, with cooler overnight low temperatures. Meanwhile, highly differential snow cover will expose more and more ground to the seasonally increasing sunshine... thus the overall snowmelt runoff process appears to be well underway, and some far southern basin rivers and streams could start to see open flow early next week. Generally favorable melt conditions are expected to persist through Sunday morning, with temperatures rising above freezing during the daytime and cooling below freezing at night. High temperatures will range from the upper 30s in the northern basin, along and north of U.S. Highway 2, and the low to middle 40s in the central and southern basin. Low temperatures will range through the low to middle 20s north and mid to upper 20s south. No significant precipitation is expected through Sunday morning. From Sunday night through Tuesday morning, a low pressure system moving into the Central Plains will pump warmer and stronger southerly flow into the area. Temperatures on Sunday and Monday should push into the 40s overall, edging near 50 into the far southern basin, south of Wahpeton-Breckenridge. Low temperatures could stay near to above freezing over large portions of the basin on Sunday night into Monday, and across the southern basin Monday night into Tuesday morning. This low pressure system could produce some widespread light rain or mixed rain and snow across the basin from Monday into Tuesday, with total precipitation amounts currently expected to range from one tenth to one quarter of an inch, with a 10 percent or less chance of reaching a half inch. At this time it appears that lesser overall precipitation amounts are favored for the Red River corridor, westward into North Dakota, with somewhat higher amounts favored across the forested uplands of northern and central Minnesota. From late Tuesday into the end of next week, temperatures should remain somewhat above long term normals, but within a more stable range. Highs Tuesday through Thursday are expected to range from the upper 30s to lower 40s, with nighttime lows dropping back into the 20s. No significant precipitation is expected for that mid to late week period. During the 8 to 14 day Outlook, March 24 through March 30, near normal temperatures with slightly above normal precipitation are indicated. The normal temperature range for the last week in March across the Fargo-Moorhead area and far southern Red River Basin is for highs ranging from 38 to 45 degrees and lows ranging from 26 to 31 degrees. Normal temperatures for the last week in March across the Grand Forks-East Grand Forks area has highs ranging from 35 to 43 degrees and lows ranging from 24 to 28 degrees. As open river flows kicks in, the North Central River Forecast Center will begin to issue daily 7-day deterministic river forecasts. And as conditions warrant, our office will issue any pertinent river flood warnings. For the far southern Red River Basin, this could start early next week. There will be no additional probabilistic flood outlooks issued this spring as we are moving into widespread melting and the issuance of deterministic forecasts. However, an updated thaw progress statement will be issued on Monday, March 21st, regarding the status of snowmelt, forecast weather conditions, and the impacts on future flood potential.
